reasoning: The critique targets a specific step in §3.3: the move from “bounded value over the whole universe” + “huge/infinite universe so our impact is tiny” to “practically linear, hence fussy.” That step is part of the essay’s taxonomy arguing most plausible value functions are fussy, but it’s not the core of the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ case (which also rests heavily on eutopian fragility/multiplicative factors, unbounded linear views, and bounded difference-making views). So centrality is moderate-low. The objection has real bite insofar as the essay explicitly relies on smooth/concave reasoning (“strictly concave… approximately linear”) and the critic correctly notes this does not cover non-differentiable/threshold/lexical/constraint-based bounded views; such views could avoid the linearization claim, so the section would need qualification or reworking to justify its breadth. However, the critique overreaches a bit by implying this misclassification covers “a large region” without argument, and some cited alternatives (rights constraints/lexical priorities) may fall outside the essay’s stated VNM/complete/expected-utility representability assumptions (though some thresholds can still be represented), which limits how far the objection applies. Clarity is high, dead weight low, and it stays tightly on one issue. Overall, it meaningfully weakens one argumentative route to ‘bounded views are fussy’ but doesn’t seriously threaten the essay’s broader conclusion by itself.
title: Cosmological linearization fails for non-smooth bounded value functions
